V pcs now what is the transit V PC
essentially it's a hub-and-spoke
architecture where in the transits we
have our VM series in different
availability zones for resiliency now it
provides several important use cases
obviously it allows your private data
center to connect into your AWS
environment securely it can also give
you shared connectivity between your
data centers and the added benefit of
this type of architecture it gives you a
cross account access so you can create
different V pcs or spokes as per this
diagram in different AWS accounts
obviously Amazon's best practices is to
do segregation of duties so that in one
particular account you might have
certain type particular workloads it
could be dev in another account you
might have UAT the added benefit of
that is with this particular
architecture you can have that all
leveraged from the transit or the hub
now if we drill down into the components
of this type of architecture obviously
we have our Palo Alto Networks
next-generation firewalls every M series
in two different availability zones for
resiliency they work in an
active/passive topology like I mentioned
before they can be in a single account
or multiple accounts now if we start
talking about the subscribers or the
spokes what we do is we leverage a vgw
hopefully everybody here is familiar
with the AWS vgw is that are available
this vgw
will establish a IPSec tunnel to each of
these VM series for resiliency so if we
have a problem in availability zone 2 or
availability zone 1 we have that high
availability to make sure that there's
no service impact within your
environment obviously with the VG W is
they'll connect into the VM series
through IPSec and then we're leveraging
a routing protocol called BGP over the
top so what that means is that as you
provision additional spokes everybody
will know about it because the trends
it's going to be redistributed all of
those routes the added benefit is that
as your environment scales everybody
will know about every other subnet
within the environment the other key
important thing to remember is is that
if everything will Traverse the transit
so you get full visibility from a
logging perspective and a control
perspective of what V PC talks to which
V PC now in this particular architecture
we've got a transit V PC hybrid and an
Internet gateway which is what we see a
lot of customers doing so if you think
of from this perspective this is your
traditional data center you've got dual
direct connects for resiliency
connecting in to do different VM series
within the transit hub now what happens
if you've got an application that needs
to be internet facing you need to put
load balancing
so that you can scale up and scale in
based on the demand this architecture is
great because it gives you that
flexibility not only do you have the
control in the transit but depending on
your particular use case based on your
workloads you can actually deploy
additional VM series in some of the
spokes what that means is that obviously
if you're running IPSec there's certain
limitations with the V JW's if you put
in Internet gateway directly on some of
the spokes that limitation will go away
so you'll be able to saturate the
network the other thing is is that like
I mentioned you'll be able to put load
balances in front of your web tears so
that you can scale out and scale in
based on the demand so it's a fully

series we will inject a default route to
Ethernet 1/1 which is our outside

the internet from there the enterprise
network will learn the routes
dynamically like I mentioned before so
as you spin up more spokes not only will
the transit know about it but as well as
your MPLS environment within your
organization from there the
redistribution profile will redistribute
the routes from here into the V JW's in

essentially you're going to have two
default routes this is where we will do

balancer any traffic that's originating

that's in that particular spoke
everything else that's outside of that
we'll use the native default route which
